turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Hey, I'm looking for some new games to play. I'm really in the mood for something in the strategy genre, preferably real-time.

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Okay, I can help with that! Based on your preference for real-time strategy games, I recommend checking out 'StarCraft II' or 'Company of Heroes 3'. Both are critically acclaimed and offer a lot of strategic depth. Have you played either of those?

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Yeah, I've played StarCraft II to death, and Company of Heroes 3 didn't really grab me. Anything a little less... mainstream? I'm getting kinda bored of the big names.

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Understood. How about 'Iron Harvest'? It's an alternative history RTS set in the 1920s with dieselpunk mechs. Or perhaps 'They Are Billions', which is a challenging steampunk survival RTS where you defend against massive zombie hordes. Do either of those sound appealing?

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Iron Harvest sounds interesting. But how does it compare to something like... say, Ashes of the Singularity in terms of scale and unit variety? I'm curious about the strategic depth. And also, why are so many RTS games on PC only? It's so frustrating!

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: That's a good question. While 'Ashes of the Singularity' emphasizes massive scale battles with hundreds of units, 'Iron Harvest' focuses on smaller, more tactical engagements with a stronger emphasis on cover and unit positioning. Unit variety is less expansive than 'Ashes,' but each unit has a distinct role. Regarding your second point, the prevalence of RTS games on PC is largely due to the precision offered by a mouse and keyboard, which are generally considered superior for controlling complex unit formations and resource management compared to console controllers.
